item.title: Buffalo Bill
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Publisher: TV Boardman Publication Dates: Christmas 1949 – 1960 Number of Issues Published: 12 (#1 – #12) Color: Colour Paper Stock: Hardcover with Dustjacket Binding: Bound Publishing Format: was ongoing series Publication Type: book Numbering continues with Buffalo Bill True West Annual (T. V. Boardman, 1961 series) #13 One of Boardman’s traditional British comic/story annuals […]
item.content:encoded:
Publisher: TV Boardman
Publication Dates: Christmas 1949 – 1960
Number of Issues Published: 12 (#1 – #12)
Color: Colour
Paper Stock: Hardcover with Dustjacket
Binding: Bound
Publishing Format: was ongoing series
Publication Type: book

Numbering continues with Buffalo Bill True West Annual (T. V. Boardman, 1961 series) #13

One of Boardman’s traditional British comic/story annuals that accompanied their Rotogravure series. Others were the Adventure Annual series and the New Spaceways Comic Annual. These British annuals feature a mixture of comics, activities, and illustrated text stories. The dust jacket and board covers have the same painted illustration.

Information thanks to the Grand Comics Database

Buffalo Bill Painting And Colouring Book

item.title: Knowledge
item.dc:creator: boutje777
item.description: Knowledge was a British weekly educational magazine for children which was assembled in blue binders into an encyclopedia. The magazine was launched by Purnell and Sons on 9 January 1961, as “Knowledge: the new colour magazine which grows into an encyclopdia” (subsequently “the colour magazine which grows into an encyclopdia”) at a price of two […]
item.content:encoded:
Knowledge was a British weekly educational magazine for children which was assembled in blue binders into an encyclopedia.

The magazine was launched by Purnell and Sons on 9 January 1961, as “Knowledge: the new colour magazine which grows into an encyclopdia” (subsequently “the colour magazine which grows into an encyclopdia”) at a price of two shillings per issue (the pre-decimal equivalent of 10p; a later re-issued run was priced as 2/6 or 12p). Sixteen volumes of twelve issues each were initially planned, but two additional volumes brought the total to eighteen. There was also a four-volume alphabetical topic guide in slightly smaller yellow binders, also assembled from parts inserted into the main magazine.

The majority of the covers of the first 192 issues (volumes 1-16) were the work of illustrator Alessandro Fedini, but the covers of the additional issues 193-216 (volumes 17 and 18) depicted twentieth century events and news headlines.

Knowledge was a British version of the Italian magazine Conoscere published by Fratelli Fabri Editori of Milan. The concept of a British edition had first been pitched to Fleetway Publications Ltd who turned it down fearing it would damage sales of their own The Children’s Encyclopdia and The Children’s Newspaper. Following the success of Knowledge, Fleetway brought out Look and Learn in 1962.

Knowledge sold 400,000 copies and was edited by John Paget Chancellor (1927-2014), son of Sir Christopher Chancellor, father of actress Anna Chancellor and brother of journalist Alexander Chancellor. The advisory editorial board of Knowledge was Christopher N. L. Brooke M.A., Violet Bonham Carter D.B.E, Norman Fisher M.A., Walter Hamilton M.A., John Sparrow M.A., L. Dudley Stamp C.B.E. D.Sc., and George Thomson F.R.S. D.Sc. In later editions John Chancellor became editor-in-chief with William Armstrong B.A. as editor and Christopher Falkus B.A. (son of Hugh Falkus) as assistant editor. The magazine ceased publication in 1966.

It’s impossible to sort them by year or volume. The scanner, who wants to stay unknown numbered them in sequence 1-216 and on the covers and inside
most issues are no dates.
